text:
# 
# 
Field Research Corporation 601 California Street, Suite 900 San Francisco, CA  94108-2814 (415) 392-5763  FAX: (415) 434-2541 EMAIL: fieldpoll@field.com www.field.com/fieldpollonline 
Release #2387 
Release Date: Tuesday, September 20, 2011 
# 
IMPORTANT: Contract for this service is subject to revocation if publication or broadcast takes place before release date or if contents are divulged to persons outside of subscriber staff prior to release time. (ISSN 0195-4520) 
By Mark DiCamillo and Mervin Field 
Having served about nine months into what is essentially his third term as governor, Jerry Brown's job performance is viewed favorably voters.  Statewide $49\%$ approve and $32\%$ disapprove of the job Brown is doing. 
The governor's ratings are considerably better than those given the state legislature.  That body is viewed favorably by just $20\%$ , while $65\%$ disapprove.  In addition, the Poll finds that voters hold negative views about both Democratic and Republican members, with majorities disapproving of the job that each party is doing. 
Californians offer a mixed assessment of the spending cuts made by Brown and the legislature in this year's state budget.  About one in four voters $(27\%)$ thinks the budget cuts went too far, while one in three $(33\%)$ believe they didn't go far enough.  Another $29\%$ think they were about right. 
However, by a greater than two to one margin ( $66\%$ to $24\%$ ), voters disapprove of the provision in the state budget agreement that calls for automatic spending cuts to be made in many of the state's major program areas, including the K-12 schools, higher education and health care, if tax revenues do not meet original assumptions. 
These are the findings from the latest Field Poll conducted in English and Spanish among a random sample of 1,001 registered voters September 1–12. 
# 
Brown's approval rating with voters has remained largely unchanged in three Field Poll measurements taken this year.  In March $48\%$ of voters approved, in June it was $46\%$ , while now $49\%$ of voters say they approve of his performance.

The proportion of voters who disapprove of the job the governor is doing $(32\%)$ is also largely unchanged from June, when it stood at $31\%$ . 
Democrats are highly supportive of the governor, approving of his performance $64\%$ to $18\%$ .  By an almost five to three margin ( $49\%$ to $32\%$ ), non-partisans also approve of the way Brown is handling his duties.  Among Republicans, about twice as many disapprove $(53\%)$ as approve $(27\%)$ of his performance, and $21\%$ are undecided.

\end{tabular}

\* Small sample base.

# 
In contrast to Brown's generally positive job appraisal, the state legislature is viewed in a very negative light by voters.  This continues a trend that has been in evidence in each of ten previous Field Poll surveys over the past three years. 
At present, just one-fifth $(20\%)$ of voters approve of the way Sacramento lawmakers are doing their jobs, while $65\%$ disapprove.  Fifteen percent have no opinion. 
While all partisan groups – Democrats, Republicans and non-partisans – view the legislature negatively, the extent of disapproval varies.  Among Democrats $53\%$ disapprove, among Republicans it is $80\%$ , while $66\%$ of non-partisans also disapprove.

# 
A majority of voters $(55\%)$ disapproves of the job that Democrats in the legislature are doing, while $31\%$ approve.  Republicans in the legislature are viewed even more unfavorably than their Democratic counterparts.  Statewide about two in three $(64\%)$ disapprove of how they are handling their jobs, while $22\%$ approve. 
Rank-and-file Democratic voters view their party's legislative members a little more favorably $(50\%)$ than unfavorably $(38\%)$ .  On the other hand, Republicans rate Democratic lawmakers harshly ( $79\%$ disapprove vs. $10\%$ approve).  Non-partisans also rate Democratic legislators negatively by greater than a two to one margin – $56\%$ to $26\%$ . 
Three fourths $(75\%)$ of Democratic voters are critical of GOP lawmakers and only $13\%$ approve of them.  Non-partisan voters also have a very negative view of Republican legislators, with $65\%$ disapproving and $22\%$ approving.  Even among their own rank-and-file,  Republican legislators are viewed more unfavorably $(46\%)$ than favorably $(36\%)$ .

# 
Voters offer mixed assessments of the spending cuts made by the legislature and approved by the governor in this year's state budget.  About one-quarter $(27\%)$ think they went too far, but one in three $(33\%)$ believe they didn't go far enough.  Another three in ten $(29\%)$ believe they were about right. 
There are some differences in the views that Democratic and Republican voters have of the budget cuts.  While a small plurality of Democrats $(35\%)$ believe the cuts went too far, among Republicans about half $(49\%)$ believe they didn't go far enough. 

\begin{tabular}{llll}
\multicolumn{4}{l}{Table 4 Voter opinions of the spending cuts approved by Governor Brown and the state legislature as part of this year's budget} \\
 & (among registered voters) &  & Non- partisans/ others \\
Spending cuts... & Total & DemocratsRepublicans \\
Went too far & 27% & 35% 20% & 21% \\
Were about right & 29 & 34 20 & 30 \\
Did not go far enough & 33 & 21 49 & 35 \\
No opinion & 11 & 10 11 & 14 \\
\end{tabular}


# 
One provision of this year's budget agreement states that if tax revenues do not meet original budget assumptions, there would be automatic spending cuts to many of the state’s major program areas, including the K-12 schools, higher education and health care. 
By a greater than two to one margin ( $66\%$ to $24\%$ ), voters think this automatic spending cuts provision was a bad idea.  Majorities of Democrats, Republicans and non-partisans all hold this view.

Table 5 Views of the state budget's automatic spending cuts provision that would reduce the K-12 schools, higher education and health care budgets should tax revenues not meet original budget assumptions (among registered voters) 
\begin{tabular}{lllll}
\multirow{2}{*}{} & \multirow{2}{*}{Total} & \multicolumn{3}{l}{Non-} \\
 &  & Democrats & Republicans & partisans/ others \\
Good idea & 24% & 20% & 31% & 23% \\
Bad idea & 66 & 74 & 59 & 63 \\
No opinion & 10 & 6 & 10 & 14 \\
\end{tabular}


# 
The general belief that things in the state are seriously off on the wrong track continues. 
Over the last three years between $70\%$ and $81\%$ of voters subscribed to the view that the state was seriously off on the wrong track.  While this negative assessment narrowed somewhat earlier this year, it continues to include two in three voters.   At present, $65\%$ view the direction of the state negatively, while $24\%$ see it moving in the right direction. 
Majorities of Democrats, Republicans, and non-partisans all believe the state is seriously off on the wrong track, although the proportion of Democrats who say this $(54\%)$ is somewhat less than Republicans $(82\%)$ and non-partisans $(65\%)$ .

# 
# 
The findings in this report are based on a Field Poll survey completed September 1-12, 2011 among a random sample of 1,001 registered voters in California. In order to cover a broad range of issues and minimize respondent fatigue, some of the questions in this release were asked of a random subsample of 520 voters. 
Interviewing was conducted by telephone in English and Spanish using live interviewers working from Field Research Corporation’s central location telephone interviewing facilities. Up to six attempts were made to reach, screen and interview each randomly selected voter on different days and times of day during the interviewing period. 
Interviewing was completed on either a voter’s landline phone or a cell phone depending on the source of the telephone listing from the voter file. After the completion of interviewing, the overall registered voter sample was weighted to Field Poll estimates of the characteristics of the registered voter population in California by region, age, gender and party registration. 
Sampling error estimates applicable to the results of any probability-based survey depend on sample size as well as the percentage distribution being examined. The maximum sampling error estimates for results based on the overall registered voters sample is $+/-3.2$ percentage points at the $95\%$ confidence level, while findings based on voters included in the random subsample have a maximum sampling error of $+/-4.4$ percentage points. The maximum sampling error is based on results in the middle of the sampling distribution (i.e., percentages at or near $50\%$ ). Percentages at either end of the distribution (those closer to $10\%$ or $90\%$ ) have a smaller margin of error. 
There are other potential sources of error in surveys besides sampling error. However, the overall design and execution of the survey sought to minimize these other possible sources of error. 
The Field Poll was established in 1947 as The California Poll by Mervin Field, who is still an active advisor. The Poll has operated continuously since then as an independent, non-partisan survey of California public opinion. The Poll receives annual funding from media subscribers of The Field Poll, from several California foundations, and the University of California and California State University systems, who receive the data files from each Field Poll survey shortly after its completion for teaching and secondary research purposes. 
# 
Thinking about this state overall, do you think things in California are generally going in the right direction or do you feel things are seriously off on the wrong track?\* 
Do you approve or disapprove of the way Jerry Brown is handling his job as Governor of California? 
Overall, do you approve or disapprove of the way the California state legislature is doing its job?\* 
What about the Democrats in the state legislature? Do you approve or disapprove of the way the Democrats in the legislature are doing their job?\* 
What about the Republicans in the state legislature? Do you approve or disapprove of the way the Republicans in the legislature are doing their job?\* 
How much confidence do you have in Governor Brown in dealing with matters relating to the state budget – a great deal of confidence, some confidence or not much confidence? 
How much confidence do you have in the state legislature in dealing with matters relating to the state budget – a great deal of confidence, some confidence or not much confidence? 
What is your opinion of the spending cuts that the Governor and state legislature made to pass this year's state budget? Do you think the cuts in state spending went too far, not far enough or were about right? 
One of the provisions included in this year's state budget is that if state tax revenues in the first half of the year fall short of a certain target, this would trigger automatic spending cuts in program areas like k-12 education, higher education and health care. Do you think that including this provision into the state budget agreement was a good idea or a bad idea?
